description: You can only use for 60 days and the pay. Didn't even bother to use it.

Beeen using Reaper for nearly a decade now and love it. The built-in plugins are really high quality, but it's definitely more difficult to use 3rd party plugins since most of them are written for MacOS and Windows with no Linux version. That's no Reaper's fault, though, and there are workarounds
summary: Happy user for over a decade

description: This version is the same as on PC\Mac. You get a 60 free trial, but they never lock you out of the program if you dont pay. Shame on user Derek for their 1* review.
Hands down the best DAW experience on Linux. 60 dollars is a slam dunk deal for the value on offer.

looking into the amount of functionality this DAW provides is honestly a deep rabbit hole, so many possiblities from custom actions to scripts to even an optional package manager that can be added in to download additional scripts, extensions, plugins, actions etc. 100/10 DAW

Reaper is an absolute masterwork. I use it for everything from audio recording to live sound and even video work. It is highly stable and customisable and well worth the price of the full licence.

To the people who leave anything other than a five star review: please don't review Reaper if you simply haven't taken the time to learn how to use it properly.
The best DAW on Linux and most CPU friendly.
setting up plugin paths for flatpak stuff is a chore and i still get some crashes but i prefer this to having to reinstall the binary everytime theres an update.
summary: reaper is a great daw and this flatpak makes it pretty convenient

description: Stuck on scanning MIDI Hardware on Linux Mint 21.3

it doesnt scale, windows cant be resized, text is way too small. This is not a Linux application.

Thanks for packaging it, but the developers need to adapt it A LOT. It has to use portals, integrate into desktops, use some actually modern styling and have basic application functionality like resizing.

This is demo software, you need a paid license to actually use it. Once it gets better on Wayland KDE, maybe worth it.

Very professional DAW, works flawless under Linux and you can even use Windows VSTs if you install yabridge. The price is always very fair and you can try it for free, basically as long as you want, like WinRaR ;)
The best DAW i've ever used and way more noob friendly than Ardour, even though you may need to look up some things on youtube.

Es una excelente herramienta de edición multimedia. me permite acortar los videos que tienen varios sectores de silencio.
Para Linux ha sido la única que puede hacer esa tarea!
